intro: Byrsocarpus puberulus, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a low-growing perennial herb with a fibrous root system adapted to survive in dry, sandy soils. The plant produces small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in late spring, followed by distinctive, spiny fruits that contain the seeds. Its leaves are covered in fine hairs, which help reduce water loss and protect against intense sunlight. The botanical features of Byrsocarpus puberulus make it well-suited for xerophytic environments and contribute to its ecological role in desert ecosystems.
